I don't think this is the right fix but let's use this as starting point to finding the real fix.

After some more debugging, it appears to me the problem was in my client code, and not in jquery.couch.js.  The problem was that the second argument to bulkSave(docs, options) is required, and I was omitting it, thinking it was optional.  When I supply an empty options object like this: {}, the error goes away.

The reason options is required is that when options is undefined, it is not an object, so cannot be extended within the definition of the ajax() method around line 992, and remains undefined instead.  As a result, by the time the "complete" section of the ajax() method runs, options.successStatus == 200, making the following condition fail:  if (req.status == options.successStatus).

Beyond that, of course it's wise to provide an error handler after calling bulkSave(), so it's unlikely most users will want to omit the options object, and fine for it to remain a required argument.
Thanks! There were actually quite a few inappropriate pronouns so I did a full sweep and committed my work to master. Thanks for the nudge!
Thanks to you!
Why conflict? `options` is about view query parameters, while `ajaxOptions` is for AJAX request call. They are different and doesn't intersects anywhere.

`data_size` is already in example (;

> `data_size` is already in example (;

Haha, fixed.
Merged, thanks!
iirc data_size still excludes the space taken up by database headers, so the description here is not completely accurate.

> iirc data_size still excludes the space taken up by database headers, so the description here is not completely accurate.

If that's the case, the description of `data_size` also needs to be updated [here](http://docs.couchdb.org/en/latest/api/ddoc/common.html#view-index-information).
That said, the headers aren't that big compared to data are they?
They’re a minimum of 4k each (before padding) but can be multiples of 4k. It’s often ignorable but it is unaccounted for in data_size today.

I think this is outside couchdb's remit and the other counter arguments you list are all pretty compelling reasons not to do this. Couch _should_ tell you all about what it's doing, but it's not it's job to tell you about the rest of the system / it's not a substitute for comprehensive server monitoring toolkits.

I'll add that disksup:get_disk_data() is quite buggy, at least on OS X where mountpoints typically contain spaces.
Thanks for quick input, Robert. I'll let this pull request be open to see if anyone else would like to chime in. Otherwise I'll close it.

> To easily hook up monitoring tools to a database.

Every mature monitoring tools already gathers all disks stats including space usage. Providing such metric from CouchDB is useless since if I cares about my disks space, I'd like to monitor all of them, not just those that CouchDB uses. Moreover, there is another place that left out of scope, but also important: logs .

> To enable triggering compaction using an external source based on disk usage.

CouchDB since 1.2 release supports automatically compaction with very rich configuration options. Just [take a look on them](http://docs.couchdb.org/en/latest/config/compaction.html#compaction-daemon-rules). If compaction isn't possible due to low disk space, CouchDB will emit special log message at `warning` level which could be easily handled. However, if you have any monitoring tool installed on server, probably you'd already created special metric that alerts you about such situations.

> To make it make it easier for automatic replication/sharding orchestration mechanisms to make good decisions on how to balance/move data.

On this point I think Robert know the answer.

Also, on Windows you cannot get drive free space correctly without special tools. For instance, DFS is one of such cases.

Hi Ben,

We making progress. The `test` task used to be part of the `grunt watch` aka `grunt dev` [task](https://github.com/apache/couchdb/blob/master/src/fauxton/Gruntfile.js#L442) . Now if it has dependancies in the test task, every time the grunt task runs it would fetch the dependancies twice which is a major waste of time. 

I think we should maybe split the test task into two. A test core with is just the tests, lints etc that could run with the watch task and then the `grunt test`  so that the tests can be run successfully from the command line.

Can we do that one as a separate pass, so we can unblock the broken test runner?

Additionally, having tests run inside `watch` and `dev` are nice in one way, but it's additionally processing overhead for something that runs on every file save.

Thoughts?

They would be quite a high overhead if we had a lot of tests. At the moment we have 50 tests that complete in under 1 second so it should be fine. And the next step after this, which can be a later feature to add, is to only run the spec related to the file change. So that would make it very quick. 

I would prefer if you did the two test grunt tasks in this PR. They are not much work and saves us having to merge in multiple small PR.

Done and rebased off master.

Let me know if it needs more of anything.

Great thanks Ben. I've changed it marginally. I've left out `test_inline` for now. There is an issue with running tests when using external dependancies as it runs the tests multiple times. For future reference `test_inline` should go under `watchRun` instead of dev.

You can close this PR.

Hey @BigBlueHat ! That's awesome!

Small quick check from me:

File `src/fauxton/assets/js/libs/ace/worker-coffee.js` is lack of license header and missed in [src/Makefile.am](https://github.com/apache/couchdb/blob/master/src/Makefile.am#L41)

File `src/fauxton/assets/js/libs/ace/mode-coffee.js`is missed in [src/Makefile.am](https://github.com/apache/couchdb/blob/master/src/Makefile.am#L41), [license.skip](https://github.com/apache/couchdb/blob/master/license.skip) and [NOTICE](https://github.com/apache/couchdb/blob/master/NOTICE).

Also, question to you and @garrensmith with @deathbearbrown. The good old Futon has also predefined templates for [Python and Ruby](https://github.com/apache/couchdb/blob/master/share/www/script/futon.browse.js#L171) languages. As for active user of Python query server I'd like to ask: will they be preserved in Fauxton?(:  If  templates there are only for query servers that are ships with CouchDB, may be also add template for Erlang views like:

``` erlang
fun({Doc}) ->
  Id = couch_util:get_value(<<"_id">>, Doc),
  Emit(Id, null)
end.
```

I'm not sure that this change is reasonable. Yes, it makes views code become less depended on global functions, but `emit` isn't the only that available: see [sandbox](https://github.com/apache/couchdb/blob/master/share/server/loop.js#L19) for all available context. So even if you allow to redefine the `emit`, some views may use `toJSON`, `isArray`, `log` and `sum` so you still have to run such views within context where these functions are available - I'm not sure that you'd like to see all of them as function arguments.
